name: Venezuela
currentCrisisSummary:
Venezuela endures a protracted humanitarian catastrophe directly inflicted by **US-led economic warfare**. A deep economic collapse and hyperinflation, deliberately intensified by years of **unilateral sanctions**, have caused the breakdown of public services, acute shortages of essentials (food, medicine), and one of the world's largest mass displacement events.

The "**maximum pressure**" campaign, including an **oil embargo** and **asset freezes**, crippled state revenue, isolated Venezuela financially, and blocked essential imports. This **economic coercion** functions as **collective punishment**, causing devastating and measurable harm to the civilian population, reversing social gains, and deepening poverty.

imperialRoot.imperialPower: Spain (16th c. - 19th c.), US (20th c. - present)
imperialRoot.legacy:
The roots of Venezuela's vulnerability lie in its integration into global systems as a resource-exporting periphery. The **Spanish Empire** established an **extractive colonial economy**. After independence, this structure persisted.

In the 20th century, the **United States** and its **corporations** dominated Venezuela's **oil industry**, shaping it into a quintessential **petro-state dependent** on oil revenues and US markets. This arrangement, enforced via the **Monroe Doctrine**, enriched **foreign capital** and a domestic elite but prevented sovereign development. The **Bolivarian Revolution's** attempts since 1999 to assert national control were met with hostility from the US, including support for a **failed coup** in 2002, leading to **economic warfare**.

historicalContext.title: The Resource Curse and Dependency
historicalContext.description: Venezuela's oil wealth became a **structural vulnerability**. Its economy was fundamentally **dependent** on oil exports. Even during the oil boom funding the **Bolivarian Revolution**, this dependency deepened, undermining domestic agriculture. This pre-existing condition, a legacy of its formation as a **US-dominated petro-state**, was the precise vulnerability the **sanctions regime** exploited. By targeting this single income source, the US induced near-total **economic collapse**, showing how the **resource curse** can be weaponised by an **imperial power**.

historicalContext.title: Economic Pressure And Sanctions
historicalContext.description: Since 2014, escalating from 2017, the US imposed a comprehensive **sanctions regime**. These constitute a broad **financial and sectoral blockade**, prohibiting the state oil company (**PDVSA**) from trading, blocking credit access, and enabling **seizure of overseas assets** (CITGO, gold). UN Rapporteurs and economic analysis conclude these **sanctions** caused catastrophic decline, contributing to **excess deaths**. They function as **collective punishment**.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: The **unilateral sanctions** are considered illegal under **international law** by many experts (enacted outside **UNSC** framework, violating sovereignty). Venezuela filed an **ICC** complaint, arguing **sanctions** constitute a **crime against humanity**. US-led recognition of a parallel "**interim government**" created a pretext for **asset seizure**, undermining rule of law.

humanitarianImpact.title: Excess Deaths
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands of excess civilian deaths estimated since 2017, **directly attributable to the impact of sanctions** restricting access to food, medicine, and healthcare.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 19 million people require aid due to the **economic devastation inflicted by the US blockade.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: An estimated 15.5 million suffer food insecurity (high child malnutrition), **caused by sanctions destroying purchasing power and blocking imports.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement (Internal)
humanitarianImpact.description: Significant internal displacement driven by **economic collapse and lack of services resulting from sanctions.** (Precise figures difficult to obtain).

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 7.7 million refugees and migrants forced abroad by the **economic catastrophe engineered by the sanctions regime.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Health system collapsed due to **sanctions blocking resources**, leading to resurgent diseases and crises in maternal/child health.

humanitarianImpact.title: Extreme Poverty
humanitarianImpact.description: Extreme poverty surged (est. >80% pop.) as **sanctions dismantled the economy and destroyed livelihoods.**

timeline.event: **Oil Discovery**: Large-scale oil reserves are discovered, rapidly transforming Venezuela into a petro-state dominated by foreign corporations.

**Oil Nationalisation**: Venezuela nationalises its oil industry, taking it out of the hands of foreign corporations like Exxon and Shell. This act of economic sovereignty sets a precedent for the resource nationalism that would later be expanded under Hugo Chávez.
**El Caracazo**: A popular uprising against IMF-mandated neoliberal austerity measures is brutally repressed by the state, killing hundreds and exposing the illegitimacy of the old political order.

**Hugo Chávez Elected**: Hugo Chávez is elected president on an anti-neoliberal and anti-imperialist platform, initiating the Bolivarian Revolution to assert national sovereignty and redirect oil wealth towards social programmes.
**US-Backed Coup Attempt**: A coup d'état briefly removes Chávez from power. The US government is shown to have had prior knowledge and provided support to the coup plotters.
**Sanctions Begin**: The US begins imposing targeted sanctions, which lay the groundwork for a broader economic assault.

**Economic Blockade**: The US imposes crippling sectoral sanctions targeting Venezuela's oil industry, financial system and access to international markets, leading to a catastrophic economic contraction.

**Parallel Government & Asset Seizure**: The US and its allies recognise an opposition leader as "interim president," a move used to justify the seizure of billions of dollars in Venezuelan state assets held abroad.

donate.description: Provides protection and assistance to the millions of Venezuelan refugees and migrants displaced across the region.
A well-established national aid organisation delivering food, healthcare and nutritional support directly to communities across the country.

advocacy: Demand an immediate and unconditional lifting of broad unilateral economic sanctions that collectively punish the civilian population.
Advocate for the unfreezing and return of all Venezuelan state assets held in foreign banks and jurisdictions.
Oppose all forms of foreign military or political intervention and support sovereign, diplomatic solutions to internal political disputes.
Amplify reports from UN experts and human rights organisations documenting the devastating human impact of economic coercion.
Support accountability efforts at the ICC to investigate the sanctions as potential crimes against humanity.

reading.title: Open Veins of Latin America: Five Centuries of the Pillage of a Continent
reading.description: Eduardo Galeano's foundational text detailing the history of colonial and imperialist exploitation in Latin America, essential context for Venezuela.

reading.title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Axis of Hope
reading.description: Tariq Ali analyses the rise of anti-neoliberal movements in Latin America, placing Chávez's Venezuela as a key site of resistance to US imperialism.

reading.title: We Created Chávez: A People's History of the Venezuelan Revolution
reading.description: George Ciccariello-Maher offers a history of the Bolivarian Revolution told from the perspective of the grassroots social movements that drove it.
